Thanks David, have copied this info for future reference! Need to buy a few more such references.

Ron
STL
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: David Zincavage 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, November 16, 2005 5:50 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba Mystery


  You can find a lot of good motif discussions in:

  Baird, Merrily. Symbols of Japan -Thematic Motifs in Art and Design, New York: 

           Rizzoli International Publications Inc., 2001. 



  My whole reference shell includes:



  An Illustrated Encyclopedia of Japanese Family Crests, Tokyo: Graphic-Sha Publishing, 2001.  



  Baird, Merrily. Symbols of Japan -Thematic Motifs in Art and Design, New York: 

           Rizzoli International Publications Inc., 2001. 



  Dower, John W.  The Elements of Japanese Design - A Handbook of Family Crests,

            Heraldry & Symbolism, New York: Weatherhill, (1971) 1979.



  Edmunds, Will H.  Pointers and Clues to the Subjects of Chinese and Japanese Art, 

                Chicago: Art Media Resources, Ltd., (1934) N.D. 



  Joly, Henri I. Legend in Japanese Art - A Description of Historical Episodes, Legendary

         Characters, Folk-Lore, Myths, Religious Symbolism, Illustrated in the Arts of Old 

        Japan, Rutland, Vermont: Charles E. Tuttle Company, (1908), 1967.



  Matsuya Piece-Goods Store, translated by Fumie Adachi,. Japanese Design Motifs, New 

                                               York: Dover, 1972. 

  -published originally in Japan in 1913.



  Motoji, Niwa and Sadao, Hibi translated by Jay W. Thomas. Snow, Wave, Pine -

                                        Traditional Patterns in Japanese Design, New York: Kodansha 

                                        International Ltd., 2001.


  Papinot, E., Historical and Geographical Dictionary of Japan, Rutland, Vermont: 
                   Charles E. Tuttle Company, 1972. 



  Turnbull, Stephen, Samurai Heraldry, Oxford: Osprey Publishing, 2002. 



  Williams, C.A.S. Outlines of Chinese Symbolism & Art Motives, Shanghai: Kelly and 

                            Walsh, 1941, New York: Dover, 1976.





    ----- Original Message ----- 
    From: Ron Hartmann 
    To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
    Sent: Wednesday, November 16, 2005 3:21 PM
    Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba Mystery


    Interesting to read this, David. The meaning of the "clouds" really surprised me. Never read that explanation before!  

    Ron
    STL
      ----- Original Message ----- 
      From: David Zincavage 
      To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
      Sent: Wednesday, November 16, 2005 12:11 PM
      Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba Mystery


      There's a brief discussion of the Ura-Manji here:

      http://www.zincavage.org/AkasakaClouds.html

      Despite the name of the url, that tsuba is probably Bushu Ito.

      David zincavage 
        ----- Original Message ----- 
        From: pac0datac0 
        To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
        Sent: Wednesday, November 16, 2005 10:02 AM
        Subject: [nihontostudy] Tsuba Mystery


        Recently I bought a WWII Officer's Katana. I've been trying to do 
        research on it and I'm a little puzzled. The Tsuba has 4 or 5 
        swastikas (can't remember how many exactly) carved into the Tsuba. I 
        found out that swastikas are buddhist symbols as well as what Hitler 
        used them for. There are designs of painted fish on the scabbard as 
        well as the handle. Which are also buddhist symbols. Has anyone else 
        ever seen Katanas decorated with swastikas? I was just wondering if 
        someone might have any background info. Any help would be great. 
        Please e-mail me back with any info.
